Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Vertically Integrated Training with Genomics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award is built around two grand challenges in biology: 1) How do genomes interact with the environment to produce biological diversity? and 2) How are biological systems integrated from molecules to ecosystems? Our training model is aimed at preparing students so that they are empowered to learn how an organism?s traits emerge from, and are continually shaped by, a complex interplay of genetic information stored in DNA and environmental information that an organism experiences throughout its life. This training will equip students with the knowledge, tools and perspectives needed to address pressing scientific and societal problems, including: effects of climate change on agriculture and food security; responses of organisms and ecosystems to anthropogenic influences on landscapes; emergence of infectious diseases, and influences of genes on behavior.

This proposal uses a ?back-to-the-future? educational model that asserts that the best way to use genomics to address grand challenges in biology is to have a graduate program that blends state-of-the-art training in genomics with an integrated, taxon-oriented, perspective. Our guiding principle is that to be able to use powerful new genomic resources as effectively as possible, students need to have strong foundation in the basic biology of the organisms they are studying. Another cornerstone of this IGERT is the recruiting and mentoring of underrepresented minorities into a scientific discipline. Because genomic topics often deal with provocative issues, students will also get training in scientific ethics and on how to communicate sensitive topics to the public.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our IGERT training grant, Vertically Integrated Training with Genomics, employed an educational model that united state-of-the-art training in genomics and bioinformatics, with a vertically integrated, taxon-centered expertise. Students were mentored in research emphasizing on two recently identified grand challenges of biology: 1) How do genomes interact with the environment to produce biological diversity? and 2) How are biological systems integrated from molecules to ecosystems? Our educational model emphasized professional development, learning to work in research teams, and communicating scientific findings to the public.

Our training model also targeted students representing a wide spectrum of disciplines, from field biologists, to lab scientists and computer programmers. In addition to courses and publishing research, IGERT Fellows and mentors conducted public outreach and developed curricula for K-12 educational programs. Moreover, dozens of animal and plant genomes were sequenced, annotated and published, and the genomic databases we created are publicly available, making them an invaluable resource to the entire scientific community.

We recruited our first cohort of students in 2012. Between August 2012 and June 2018, the major outcomes of our training grant include:

Thirty-nine students were supported by IGERT as Fellows including 23 (59%) women, and 15 (38%) students from under-represented groups (African American, Hispanic and Native American). Our Fellows were enrolled in eight different departments from three different Colleges across the University. As of June 1, 2018, 68 peer-reviewed papers were published with IGERT Fellows as authors, and a total of 641 papers were published by IGERT Fellows, advisors and co-mentors. Many of these publications appeared in the top journals including 22 in Nature / Science and 18 in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. IGERT Fellows also gave 133 research presentations and IGERT Fellows, advisors and co-mentors engaged with the public through outreach and educational opportunities over 260 times.

In addition, a number of courses developed for our students are now part of the University of Illinois’ curriculum including a Graduate orientation course and genomic / bioinformatic courses. We also developed new partnerships between faculty at Illinois and the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute as part of co-mentoring model and these international collaborations continue.
